newsitem.title: UK: Licht sees lower world sugar output for 1996/97.
newsitem.headline: Licht sees lower world sugar output for 1996/97.

text.p: World sugar production in the 1996/97 crop year (Sept/Aug) should fall to 123.95 million tonnes raw value from 125.54 million the year previously. statistician F.O. Licht said on Wednesday. With sugar disappearance forecast at 119.62 million tonnes for 1996/97, after 116.78 million in 1995/96, Licht said world sugar stocks could expect another rise with an increase in the stocks/consumption percentage ratio.

"Even after taking into consideration about one million tonnes of unrecorded disappearance, that points to a further substantial hoist to world stocks with the stock/consumption ratio rising to 42.27 percent from 40.39 percent and less than 28 percent at the end of the 1980s," Licht said.
In its first estimate of the 1996/97 balance, Licht said surplus stocks were forecast to rise to 10.6 million tonnes.
It forecast ending world stocks at 50.57 million tonnes in 1996/97, compared with 47.16 million in 1995/96.
"The upward trend in production appears to have come to n end," Licht said, adding that a healthy increase in consumption was in prospect.
"These are welcome signs but the enormous stocks overhanging the market must not be overlooked," it said.
Imports were pegged at 35.41 million tonnes, down from 37.39 million in 1995/96, while exports were also expected to be lower, estimated at 36.35 million from a previous 38.22 million.
Licht said one reason for the lower output figure was that several countries were likely to produce reduced crops in 1997/98, which would affect the 1996/97 estimate for the September/August year.
"Consequently in some cases, as for instance Brazil, the early months of the crop year 1996/97 are excluded while the corresponding early months of crop year 1997/98 are included," it said.
Other factors were the probability of a lower crop in Cuba as a result of Hurricane Lili and a lower-than-expected crop in Thailand following heavy rains.
Pakistan would produce less sugar then originally expected because of increased diversion of cane to producers of gur.
